statements.name: PROC PLS
statements.description: The PLS procedure fits models by using any one of a number of linear predictive methods, including partial least squares (PLS). Ordinary least squares regression, as implemented in SAS/STAT procedures such as PROC GLM and PROC REG, has the single goal of minimizing sample response prediction error, seeking linear functions of the predictors that explain as much variation in each response as possible. The techniques implemented in the PLS procedure have the additional goal of accounting for variation in the predictors, under the assumption that directions in the predictor space that are well sampled should provide better prediction for new observations when the predictors are highly correlated. All of the techniques implemented in the PLS procedure work by extracting successive linear combinations of the predictors, called factors (also called components, latent vectors, or latent variables), which optimally address one or both of these two goals—explaining response variation and explaining predictor variation. In particular, the method of partial least squares balances the two objectives, seeking factors that explain both response and predictor variation.

arguments.name: CENSCALE
arguments.description: Lists the centering and scaling information for each response and predictor.

arguments.name: CV=
arguments.description: Specifies the cross validation method to be used. By default, no cross validation is performed.

arguments.name: ONE
arguments.description: Requests one-at-a-time cross validation

arguments.name: SPLIT
arguments.description: Syntax: SPLIT<(n)> Requests that every n-th observation be excluded

arguments.name: BLOCK
arguments.description: Syntax: BLOCK<(n)> Requests that n blocks of consecutive observations be excluded

arguments.name: RANDOM
arguments.description: Syntax: RANDOM<(cv-random-opts)> Requests that observations be excluded at random. You can specify the following optional cv-random-options in parentheses: NITER=n specifies the number of random subsets to exclude. The default value is 10. NTEST=n specifies the number of observations in each random subset chosen for exclusion. SEED=n specifies an integer used to start the pseudo-random number generator for selecting the random test set.

arguments.name: TESTSET
arguments.description: Syntax: TESTSET(SAS-data-set) Specifies a test set of observations to be used for validation (formally, this is called "test set validation" rather than "cross validation").

arguments.name: CVTEST=
arguments.description: Specifies that van der Voet’s (1994) randomization-based model comparison test be performed to test models with different numbers of extracted factors against the model that minimizes the predicted residual sum of squares. You can specify the following cv-test-options: PVAL=n specifies the cutoff probability for declaring an insignificant difference. The default value is 0.10. STAT=test-statistic specifies the test statistic for the model comparison. NSAMP=n specifies the number of randomizations to perform. The default value is 1000.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set to be used by PROC PLS. The default is the most recently created data set.

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: Lists the details of the fitted model for each successive factor.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the general factor extraction method to be used.

arguments.name: PLS
arguments.description: Syntax: PLS<(PLS-options)> Requests partial least squares. You can specify the following optional PLS-options in parentheses: ALGORITHM=NIPALS | SVD | EIG | RLGW names the specific algorithm used to compute extracted PLS factors. NIPALS requests the usual iterative NIPALS algorithm, SVD bases the extraction on the singular value decomposition of X'Y, EIG bases the extraction on the eigenvalue decomposition of Y'XX'Y, and RLGW is an iterative approach that is efficient when there are many predictors. MAXITER=n specifies the maximum number of iterations for the NIPALS and RLGW algorithms. The default value is 200. EPSILON=n specifies the convergence criterion for the NIPALS and RLGW algorithms. The default value is 10⁻¹².

arguments.name: SIMPLS
arguments.description: Requests the SIMPLS method of de Jong (1993)

arguments.name: PCR
arguments.description: Requests principal components regression

arguments.name: RRR
arguments.description: Requests reduced rank regression

arguments.name: MISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how observations with missing values are to be handled in computing the fit.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Observations with any missing variables (dependent or independent) are excluded from the analysis.

arguments.name: AVG
arguments.description: Specifies that the fit be computed by filling in missing values with the average of the nonmissing values for the corresponding variable.

arguments.name: EM
arguments.description: The procedure first computes the model with MISSING=AVG and then fills in missing values by their predicted values based on that model and computes the model again. You can specify the following optional EM-options in parentheses: MAXITER=n specifies the maximum number of iterations for the imputation/fit loop. EPSILON=n specifies the convergence criterion for the imputation/fit loop. The default value for is 10⁻⁸.

arguments.name: NFAC=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of factors to extract.

arguments.name: NOCENTER
arguments.description: Suppresses centering of the responses and predictors before fitting. This is useful if the analysis variables are already centered and scaled.

arguments.name: NOCVSTDIZE
arguments.description: Suppresses re-centering and rescaling of the responses and predictors before each model is fit in the cross validation.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the normal display of results.

arguments.name: NOSCALE
arguments.description: Suppresses scaling of the responses and predictors before fitting. This is useful if the analysis variables are already centered and scaled.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Controls the plots produced through ODS Graphics. Syntax: (1) PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> <= plot-request <(options)>> (2)PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> <= (plot-request <(options)> <... plot-request <(options)>>)> The global plot options include the following: FLIP interchanges the X-axis and Y-axis dimensions for the score, weight, and loading plots. ONLY suppresses the default plots. Only plots specifically requested are displayed.
arguments.help: PLOTS=ALL | CORRLOAD | CVPLOT | DIAGNOSTICS | DMOD | DMODX | DMODXY | DMODY | FIT | NONE | PARMPROFILES | SCORES | RESIDUALS | VIP | WEIGHTS | XLOADINGPLOT | XLOADINGPROFILES | XSCORES | XWEIGHTPLOT | XWEIGHTPROFILES | XYSCORES | YSCORES | YWEIGHTPLOT

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Produces all appropriate plots.

arguments.name: CORRLOAD
arguments.description: Syntax: CORRLOAD<(TRACE = ON | OFF)> Produces a correlation loading plot (default).

arguments.name: CVPLOT
arguments.description: Produces a cross validation and R-square analysis.

arguments.name: DIAGNOSTICS
arguments.description: Syntax: DIAGNOSTICS<(UNPACK)> Produces a summary panel of the fit for each dependent variable.

arguments.name: DMOD
arguments.description: Produces the DMODX, DMODY, and DMODXY plots.

arguments.name: DMODX
arguments.description: Produces a plot of the distance of each observation to the X model.

arguments.name: DMODXY
arguments.description: Produces plots of the distance of each observation to the X and Y models.

arguments.name: DMODY
arguments.description: Produces a plot of the distance of each observation to the Y model.

arguments.name: FIT
arguments.description: Produces both the fit diagnostics and the ParmProfiles plot.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of graphics.

arguments.name: PARMPROFILES
arguments.description: Produces profiles of the regression coefficients.

arguments.name: SCORES
arguments.description: Syntax: SCORES<(UNPACK|FLIP)> Produces the XScores, YScores, XYScores, and DModXY plots.

arguments.name: RESIDUALS
arguments.description: Syntax: RESIDUALS<(UNPACK)> Plots the residuals for each dependent variable against each independent variable.

arguments.name: VIP
arguments.description: Produces profiles of variable importance factors.

arguments.name: WEIGHTS
arguments.description: Syntax: WEIGHTS<(UNPACK|FLIP)> Produces all X and Y loading and weight plots, as well as the VIP plot.

arguments.name: XLOADINGPLOT
arguments.description: Syntax: XLOADINGPLOT<(UNPACK|FLIP)> Produces a scatter plot matrix of X-loadings against each other.

arguments.name: XLOADINGPROFILES
arguments.description: Produces profiles of the X-loadings.

arguments.name: XSCORES
arguments.description: Syntax: XSCORES<(UNPACK|FLIP)> Produces a scatter plot matrix of X-scores against each other.

arguments.name: XWEIGHTPLOT
arguments.description: Syntax: XWEIGHTPLOT<(UNPACK|FLIP)> Produces a scatter plot matrix of X-weights against each other.

arguments.name: XYSCORES
arguments.description: Syntax: XYSCORES<(UNPACK)> Produces profiles of the X-weights.

arguments.name: YSCORES
arguments.description: YSCORES<(UNPACK|FLIP)> Produces a scatter plot matrix of Y-scores against each other.

arguments.name: YWEIGHTPLOT
arguments.description: Syntax: YWEIGHTPLOT<(UNPACK|FLIP)> Produces a scatter plot matrix of Y-weights against each other.

arguments.name: VARSCALE
arguments.description: Specifies that continuous model variables be centered and scaled prior to centering and scaling the model effects in which they are involved.

arguments.name: VARSS
arguments.description: Lists, in addition to the average response and predictor sum of squares accounted for by each successive factor, the amount of variation accounted for in each response and predictor.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: You can specify a BY statement with PROC PLS to obtain separate analyses on observations in groups that are defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in order of the BY variables. If you specify more than one BY statement, only the last one specified is used.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement names the classification variables to be used in the analysis. The CLASS statement must precede the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: TRUNCATE
arguments.description: Specifies that class levels should be determined by using no more than the first 16 characters of the formatted values of CLASS variables.

statements.name: EFFECT
statements.description: The name of the effect is specified after the EFFECT keyword. This name can appear in only one EFFECT statement and cannot be the name of a variable in the input data set. The effect-type is specified after an equal sign, followed by a list of variables within parentheses which are used in constructing the effect. Effect-options that are specific to an effect-type can be specified after a slash (/) following the variable list. The EFFECT statement enables you to construct special collections of columns for design matrices. These collections are referred to as constructed effects to distinguish them from the usual model effects formed from continuous or classification variables.

arguments.name: EFFECT-NAME=
arguments.description: Replace 'EFFECT-NAME' with the name of the effect, specified after the EFFECT keyword. This name can appear in only one EFFECT statement and cannot be the name of a variable in the input data set. These values can be used: COLLECTION, MULTIMEMBER, POLYNOMIAL, or SPLINE.

arguments.name: BASIS=
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies a basis for the spline expansion.

arguments.name: BSPLINE
arguments.description: Specifies a B-spline basis for the spline expansion.

arguments.name: TPF
arguments.description: Syntax: TPF(options) Specifies a truncated power function basis for the spline expansion. You can modify the number of columns when you request BASIS=TPF with the following options: NOINT excludes the intercept column. NOPOWERS excludes the intercept and polynomial columns.

arguments.name: DATABOUNDARY
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies that the extremes of the data be used as boundary knots when building a B-spline basis.

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: [For the LAG | COLLECTION | MULTIMEMBER | POLYNOMIAL |SPLINE effect-type] Requests a table that shows the (1) lag design matrix of the lag effect, or (2) constituents of the collection effect, or (3) levels of the multimember effect, or (4) details of the specified polynomial, or (5) knot locations and the knots associated with each spline basis function.

arguments.name: KNOTMETHOD=
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies how to construct the knots for spline effects.
arguments.help: KNOTMETHOD=EQUAL | LIST | LISTWITHBOUNDARY | MULTISCALE | PERCENTILES | RANGEFRACTIONS

arguments.name: EQUAL
arguments.description: Syntax: EQUAL<(n)> Specifies that n equally spaced knots be positioned between the extremes of the data. The default is n=3. For a B-spline basis, any needed boundary knots continue to be equally spaced unless the DATABOUNDARY option has also been specified. KNOTMETHOD=EQUAL is the default if no knot-method is specified.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: Syntax: LIST(number-list) Specifies the list of internal knots to be used in forming the spline basis columns. For a B-spline basis, the data extremes are used as boundary knots.

arguments.name: LISTWITHBOUNDARY
arguments.description: Syntax: LISTWITHBOUNDARY(number-list) Specifies the list of all knots that are used in forming the spline basis columns.

arguments.name: MULTISCALE
arguments.description: Syntax: MULTISCALE<(multiscale-options)> Specifies that multiple B-spline bases be generated, corresponding to sets with an increasing number of internal knots. You can control which scales are included with the following multiscale-options: STARTSCALE=n specifies the start scale, where n is a positive integer. The default is STARTSCALE=0. ENDSCALE=n specifies the end scale, where n is a positive integer. The default is ENDSCALE=7.

arguments.name: PERCENTILES
arguments.description: Syntax: PERCENTILES(n) Requests that internal knots be placed at n equally spaced percentiles of the variable or variables named in the EFFECT statement.

arguments.name: RANGEFRACTIONS
arguments.description: Syntax: RANGEFRACTIONS(fraction-list) Requests that internal knots be placed at each fraction of the ranges of the variables in the EFFECT statement.

arguments.name: EXPAND
arguments.description: Specifies that each variable with an exponent greater than 1 be written as products of that variable.

arguments.name: EXPONENT
arguments.description: Syntax: EXPONENT <=quoted string> Specifies that each variable with an exponent greater than 1 be written using exponential notation. By default, the symbol ^ is used as the exponentiation operator. If you supply the optional quoted string after an equal sign, then that string is used as the exponentiation operator.

arguments.name: INCLUDENAME
arguments.description: Specifies that the name of the effect followed by an underscore be used as a prefix for term labels.

arguments.name: PRODUCTSYMBOL=
arguments.description: Syntax: PRODUCTSYMBOL=NONE | quoted string Specifies that the supplied string be used as the product symbol.

arguments.name: NOEFFECT
arguments.description: [For the MULTIMEMBER effect-type only] Specifies that, for observations with all missing levels of the multimember variables, the values in the corresponding design matrix columns be set to zero.

arguments.name: NOSEPARATE
arguments.description: [For the POLYNOMIAL effect-type only] Specifies that the polynomial be treated as a single effect with multiple degrees of freedom. The effect name that you specify is used as the constructed effect name, and the labels of the terms are used as labels of the corresponding parameters.

arguments.name: PERIOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the period variable of the LAG design. The number of periods is the number of unique formatted values of the PERIOD= variable, and the ordering of the period is formed by sorting these formatted values in ascending order. You must specify a PERIOD= variable.

arguments.name: SEPARATE
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies that when multiple variables are specified in the EFFECT statement, the spline basis for each variable be treated as a separate effect. The names of these separated effects are formed by appending an underscore followed by the name of the variable to the name that you specify in the EFFECT statement.

arguments.name: SPLIT
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies that each individual column in the design matrix that corresponds to the spline effect be treated as a separate effect that can enter or leave the model independently. Names for these split effects are generated by appending the variable name and an index for each column to the name that you specify in the EFFECT statement.

arguments.name: STANDARDIZE
arguments.description: Specifies that the variables that define the polynomial be standardized. By default, the standardized variables receive prefix "s_" in the variable names. You can use the following centerscale-opts to specify how the center and scale are estimated: METHOD=MOMENTS specifies that the center be estimated by the variable mean and the scale be estimated by the standard deviation. METHOD=RANGE specifies that the center be estimated by the midpoint of the variable range and the scale be estimated as half the variable range. METHOD=WMOMENTS is the same as METHOD=MOMENTS except that weighted means and weighted standard deviations are used.

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: Specifies that variables be centered but not scaled.

arguments.name: CENTERSCALE
arguments.description: Specifies that variables be centered and scaled. This is the default if you do not specify a standardization-opt.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no standardization be performed.

arguments.name: SCALE
arguments.description: Specifies that variables be scaled but not centered.

arguments.name: STDIZE
arguments.description: [For the MULTIMEMBER effect-type only] Specifies that for each observation, the entries in the design matrix that corresponds to the multimember effect be scaled to have a sum of one.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement names variables whose values are used to label observations in plots. If you do not specify an ID statement, then each observations is labeled in plots by its corresponding observation number.

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement names the responses and the predictors, which determine the Y and X matrices of the model, respectively. Usually you simply list the names of the predictor variables as the model effects, but you can also use the effects notation of PROC GLM to specify polynomial effects and interactions. The MODEL statement is required. You can specify only one MODEL statement (in contrast to the REG procedure, for example, which allows several MODEL statements in the same PROC REG run).

arguments.name: INTERCEPT
arguments.description: By default, the responses and predictors are centered; thus, no intercept is required in the model. You can specify the INTERCEPT option to override the default.

arguments.name: SOLUTION
arguments.description: Lists the coefficients of the final predictive model for the responses.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: You use the OUTPUT statement to specify a data set to receive quantities that can be computed for every input observation, such as extracted factors and predicted values.

arguments.name: H=
arguments.description: Approximate leverage

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the output data set.

arguments.name: PREDICTED=
arguments.description: Predicted values for responses

arguments.name: PRESS=
arguments.description: Approximate predicted residuals

arguments.name: STDX=
arguments.description: Standardized (centered and scaled) predictors

arguments.name: STDXSSE
arguments.description: Sum of squares of residuals for standardized predictors

arguments.name: STDY=
arguments.description: Standardized (centered and scaled) responses

arguments.name: STDYSSE=
arguments.description: Sum of squares of residuals for standardized responses

arguments.name: TSQUARE=
arguments.description: Scaled sum of squares of score values

arguments.name: XRESIDUAL=
arguments.description: Residuals for predictors

arguments.name: XSCORE=
arguments.description: Extracted factors (X-scores, latent vectors, latent variables, T)

arguments.name: YRESIDUAL=
arguments.description: Residuals for responses

arguments.name: YSCORE=
arguments.description: Extracted responses (Y-scores, U)
